author: Entire_Sherbet9615
body: Mounjaro got my T2D under control and helped lower my cholesterol too. It’s just a tool in the T2D toolbox, you can only decide what is best for you. Regardless, if you feel a doctor is not listening to you, then just find a new doctor. You are in control.

author: canthearu_ack
body:
Rant away.

But apparently Ozempic is good if your A1C is too high and can often help control disordered eating.

But without any details, can't say much more than that.

If you feel your doctor is failing to listen to you, maybe try another.

author: [deleted]
body: Ozempic is bad for eating disorders. It helped me starve myself. It's bad for lots of things actually.

author: canthearu_ack
body:
I'm thinking the other way when I said that. Helping someone who eats too much feel better satisfied with regular meal serving sizes.

Ozempic absolutely has the ability to go horribly wrong as well. For many people, it is a disaster drug instead of a miracle drug.

author: sillyho3
body: Wonder if I should try it. I will eat something even if I'm uncomfortably full if I know it tastes good.

author: CopperBlitter
body:
I can't speak for Ozempic, but Mounjaro squashes that impulse in me. I open the fridge, stare at the food, then think, "nah, I'm good."

BTW, Happy Cake Day.

author: sillyho3
body: Thank you!

author: ZorroMuerte
body: The side effects eventually wear off and you go back to that disordered eating. This is what happened to me. They even increased my dosage and the side effects never came back. I still want to eat trash or overeat. Its been hard work to actually slow down my eating and think before I eat. I'm still working thorugh it and man its tough. Ozempic mainly helps you notice how badly you overeat.

author: canthearu_ack
body:
Yep, for actual disordered eating, I would recommend therapy in addition to any medications.

There is usually a lot going on there, more than you can expect any medication to just fix.

author: millwrightbob
body:
Ozempic nearly put me in the physc ward.
It made me so sick for 2 weeks. I couldn't eat. It also affected my mental state severely. I felt there was darkness and gloom all around me, and that's just not how I feel ever. It is a rare side effect A. Few people I have heard of have been hospitalized because of the same thing that happened to me. I will never go near it again.

author: [deleted]
body: Can't help but agree there. Very bad for losing muscle mass.

author: Snoogiewoogie
body: Ozempic saved me from the vicious cycle of binge eating disorder. I know others who had the same experience and it’s truly life changing. I’m sorry that it was damaging for your eating disorder.

author: [deleted]
body: I'm truly glad for you!!! That it helped.  💗💗💗 I'm a gazillion times better now thank you!!!

author: knivesforsoup
body: Sorry to hear you went through that. Hope you're doing better now. Something similar happened to me too. Had a long history of restricting before ozempic, but I didn't start >!purging!< until Ozempic made me nauseous enough to do so, and I ended up doing it even while not nauseous. With all the hype around it being a weight loss drug I wish doctors would sit down with patients and discuss any potential ED history before prescribing these meds.

author: [deleted]
body: You poor thing!!! My doctor at the time knew I had atypical anorexia and made everything be about weightloss.  I did use it to help me to fast for long periods of time. I'm much better. I went on the carnivore diet and it helped my mental health, and then it's now reversing my diabetes. I'm off one tablet now. One more tablet to go. I hope you are doing better now. 💗💗💗

author: knivesforsoup
body: Glad to hear you've found something that works for you! Sorry to hear about your doctor though. I'm still on Ozempic with a slightly reduced dosage but my Metformin dosage has halved. Was able to stop >!purging!< with therapy. I follow plant based and low carb. Carnivore sounds intriguing but for me if I restricted to one food group that would trigger my ED again. A1C is good so it works for me. Wishing you best of health ❤️

author: [deleted]
body: That's what my dietician was scared of. It was unfounded in my case at least. My heart was sick. I had tachycardia from all the fasting.  I would add meat into your diet, and meat and animal fats help our minds.  Take care.  I'm so happy for you that you've been able to stop purging. That's a big deal!!! 💗💗

author: knivesforsoup
body: I still eat plenty meat, I just eat a lot of vegetables. Did I get the meaning of plant based wrong? I thought plant based just means you eat majority vegetables like how a non diabetic typical FDA diet looks like majority carbs

author: [deleted]
body: I think plant based means vegetarian or vegan. 💗💗💗 you might be meat based.

author: 1fatsquirrel
body: Yes fair. I don’t have an eating disorder and it helped me immensely however that was something my health care provider talked with me about before prescribing. Op- we don’t know enough about your medical history to say if this was a good or bad move by the dr, however in many situations it can be a really worthwhile medication. But I also completely understand the frustration of just being shoved an Rx. I’m sorry you had a shitty experience with this Dr.

author: [deleted]
body:
I think you need a new pcp. I’m on a similar drug but had a lengthy discussion with my doc before hand and tried other things. Mounjaro has been the best thing ever to happen for me with intense diet and exercise too, but metformin couldn’t get me where I wanted to be because my hormones were out of control. 

Get you a doc that listens to you. Do what you feel is right. Ozempic is wonderful for many, but don’t feel pressured (unless you were like me, 11.1 a1c and my kidneys felt like they were falling out of my body haha- and most mornings I couldn’t feel my toes)

author: soapyrubberduck
body:
Mounjaro saved my life. I went from A1C in the upper 10s to in the lower 5s. Fasting glucose went from 350 to 90. I lost 100 pounds. I’ve never felt better than now. I tried so many diets and exercise programs for my whole life and nothing ever worked. Mounjaro was the catalyst I needed to get unstuck. My doctor recommended it to me because clearly, it’s effective. 

If you aren’t open to it, that’s fine too. This doctor doesn’t align with your goals. Go get a second opinion from a doctor who does.

author: startripjk
body: Ozempic was HORRIBLE for me! I couldn't sleep at night because of constant acid reflux/indigestion (and no...I wasn't over eating). Every night...w/ zero warning I would barf. Out of the blue. I would just be sitting, talking to my wife...then ...barf. I don't just mean "one and done". I would barf until my stomach was empty..then dry heave. F\*\*k that. Bulimia is no way to get your A1c down.

author: Icy_Cardiologist1620
body: I had similar issues. I started on a very low dose, so I didn't connect the symptoms I was having to the medication. Vomiting would hit unexpectedly with no obvious reason why. Then, as my dose was increased, it started getting ugly. We finally figured out the connection, but not before I had vomiting and diarrhea for 15 days and lost 15 pounds! Not a diet I'd recommend.

author: SaharaLee
body: I’m sorry you didn’t have a good experience but Ozempic has been a miracle drug for me.  Took my blood sugar from the 400/500s to the low 100s.  Was taking 60 units of novolog before now down to 10.

author: seb2b9
body: I’m sorry that your doctor was not listening to you, and I truly hope you get relief from your symptoms, but from your doctor’s perspective, he or she has probably seen dozens of patients deteriorate from uncontrolled diabetes at the end of their lives. While I think behavioral change is best because the medications will be there waiting if/when diabetes progresses, I understand why doctors would lead with the most cautious approach.

author: Thefawn4
body:
I had the same experience, my doctor said I should “lose weight” even though I was 175 pounds but too be honest I’m glad she put me on it. 
After the first month of taking it my blood sugar numbers dropped and between the Ozempic and Xigdou I was back down to pre-diabetic numbers.

Only bad part is it can be hard to come by at times because people abuse it.

author: principalgal
body:
I’m so sorry! I tried so many other things first. Diet, exercise, dietician, Metformin, more Metformin (🤮). I’m very lucky I have a doc who listens to me. When all of that still didn’t work, I started Ozempic. Been almost 3 weeks and my blood sugars are nearly perfect on the starter baby dose. I know it’s not for everyone, but it made the difference for me. 
That said, you deserve to be heard when it’s your health.

author: willwar63
body: Find another one.

author: EvLokadottr
body: Well, Ozempic really was a miserable for me. No other diabetes meds I had tried were getting my insulin resistance under control, even with a strict low carb diet and exercise. So.

author: MissusPringle
body: 2 years ago my A1C was 12. I tried different meds, switched my food up entirely, and my A1C went to 8. Stayed there. So my doctor gave me Ozempic. It’s keeping my A1C normal but I barely eat. Food is repulsive to me even when I have physiological hunger cues. It’s a challenge.

author: Creative_Reporter_35
body: I hope I never need it.  The side effects can be nasty, I know two people who took it and now have significant gastroparesis.

author: GrandDull
body: About how long were they on it? Is it permanent?

author: Safe-On-That
body:
Many doctors treat the symptoms and not the source of the problem…I switched and found a DO to help me.

https://osteopathic.org/what-is-osteopathic-medicine/

author: catkysydney
body:
I have been on Ozempic for 5 months, my A1c is OK, 5.5.  
Ozempic suppresses my appetite in a great deal , so it is easier to control what I eat , low carbs !
Problem for me is losing weight . I am not overweight, I did not need to lose weight, but I lost 7 kg now I am nearly underweight..
Also my blood pressure became lower , always under 100/60..
If you are overweight and with high blood pressure, this medicine is perfect .

author: bucketlovesstove
body: Meanwhile I asked about Ozempic, got a  prescription, and insurance won't pay for it even though I am diabetic. I personally know people on it who aren't even diabetic and they just take it for weight loss. Infuriating.

author: EvLokadottr
body: Well, Ozempic really was a miserable for me. No other diabetes meds I had tried were getting my insulin resistance under control, even with a strict low carb diet and exercise. So.

author: edithscissorhands
body: If you don't like doctors, don't go to them.  Get yourself a medical practitioner in the alternative medicine arena.  btw, the Harvard Medical review says the type 2s most likely to have complications later in life are the ones taking drugs.  Think about that, everyone.

author: LEH252
body: Could you post your source. I would like to see what complications people who are taking these glp1 drugs are having and how later in life is defined. It would be very helpful. Thanks

author: edithscissorhands
body: I'm searching for the original site/info I read this on, in the meantime found this.  It is in regard to drugs not many on this discussion are taking, I would bet. and are drugs prescribed to type 2s when metformin either "isn't tolerated" or is not effective [https://news.feinberg.northwestern.edu/2018/12/21/two-type-2-diabetes-drugs-linked-to-higher-risk-of-heart-disease/](https://news.feinberg.northwestern.edu/2018/12/21/two-type-2-diabetes-drugs-linked-to-higher-risk-of-heart-disease/)

author: M_Ad
body:
Is Ozempic's main utility as a weight loss aid? Pretty much all the talk about it seems to be how it's good for weight loss. Even a lot of Type 2 diabetics place emphasis on the weight loss being what has helped lower their blood sugar.

I've been finding it hard to research online and find out whether it actually does something chemically to alter blood sugar in and of itself, separate from causing weight loss that causes metabolic change causing lower blood sugar. 

I'm overweight but not by a huge amount (BMI of 26) so I know I won't benefit from the stereotypical dramatic huge weight loss that lots of people taking it seem to do. As I'm already on Vyvanse for ADHD which is also an appetite suppression, I'm not sure whether Ozempic would be redundant, if it doesn't actually chemically do anything to blood sugar, just suppresses appetite.

author: KittyCatLilly13
body:
I can’t believe some doctors just hand it out like that. After doing some research I found that it can cause gastrointestinal slowing to the point of paralysis called gastroparesis. And it doesn’t always go away when you stop taking it. It can also cause anyone predisposed to certain types of thyroid cancer to develop the cancer.  There is still so little unknown about long term side effects that I was told by my diabetes manager that she is only prescribing to people over 50, overweight, and if they have had cardiovascular problems.  I’m not sure why the cardiovascular bit but I am going to give them that. 

I don’t think less of anyone using it, if the risk and unknown is worth it to them then I support that. It’s just scary to me that doctors are so willing to prescribe it so quickly with so many risk and unknowns.

author: principalgal
body: It is supposed to be beneficial for your cardiovascular system. Positive side effect.

author: MissusPringle
body: That tracks. I’m diabetic, 57, and I have a congenital heart condition. It’s not life-threatening or even bothersome most of the time.

author: Armando_Ferriera
body: Ppl that can't diet for themselves are hooked on Ozempic and these types of drugs for life.  They stop, and the weight comes right back on.  If they have a family history of thyroid issues, good luck...

author: EvLokadottr
body: We are taking it for diabetes here, though.

author: Armando_Ferriera
body: No kidding.

author: SinisterCuttleFish
body:
Ozempic is a gamechanger for diabetics.  My blood glucose is perfect.

I'm also capable of dieting for myself as needed.  The thyroid issue is a bit of a panic merchant issue.  Rats developed thyroid cancer, there is not one case in humans.
